The Related Discourses

13. The Noble Path

10. Requirements (2)

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

It was then that the Buddha addressed the monks, “There’s what’s known as the ‘roots and many requirements of the nobles’ concentration.’ What are these roots and many requirements of the nobles’ concentration? That refers to the seven factors of the right path, which are both the roots and many requirements of the nobles’ concentration. What are the seven? They are right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness. Monks, after someone has laid the foundation of these seven factors of the path, they unify their mind. These are called the roots and many requirements of the nobles’ concentration.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This sutra is reconstituted from a description of variants found after SA 13.7. It’s a variant of SA 13.7 in which the Buddha questions the monks rather than being asked a question. It’s also parallel to SN 45.28.
Translator: Charles Patton
